amnesia-was-fir-name.raw_source: [[include :scp-wiki:theme:basalt centertitle=a|acs-itemnum=a]] ===== [[include component:preview text=How to Hire Your Dragon]] ===== [[module css]] #u-blink-bar p:last-child::after {     content: "";     border-right: 1px solid black;     animation: blink 1s infinite;     position: relative;     left: 1px; }   @keyframes blink{     to {         opacity: .0;     } } [[/module]] [[module css]] :root {     --header-logo: url('https://i.imgur.com/mXqUWsy.png');  --title: "Department of Geology";   --subtitle: "As Above, So Below"; } [[/module]] [[module css]] .green {background-color:#c9f7c8;"} } [[/module]] [[=]] [[module Rate]] [[/=]] [[=]] [[image mine1.jpg width="700px"]] [[/=]] ----- [[div class="blockquote"]] [[=]] +++ **Site-898 Internal Breach Report:** [[/=]] On 21/8/2011, a sudden thaumaturgic surge occurred within the Red Brook Mine, beneath Site-898. This surge, and subsequent geological activity, would result in a warning ping from the OROGENESIS system.[[footnote]] Site-898’s geological monitoring system and .AIC, designated as OROGENESIS.aic but often colloquially nicknamed as "Ori". Further information restricted to level 5/OROGENESIS-CORE.[[/footnote]] Upon reception, its data was put through thaumaturgic processing. This allowed it to be identified as the temporary creation of an unstable Way, and its near-immediate collapse — which had taken one of the mine’s tunnels down with it. Due to MTF Gamma-89 (“Rock and a Hard Place”) being temporarily offsite, the resultant collapse was investigated by Director Hellen Gibbs and Dr. Rudy Weller. ----- //Dr. Weller pulls open the door to the mine with a grunt, sunlight from the outside briefly filters through the dust and dirt as he and Dir. Gibbs enter and begin to head downwards. Both are dressed in high-vis PPE,[[footnote]] Personal Protection Equipment. [[/footnote]] with active headlamps.// **Dr. Weller:** I'm surprised you're the one coming down here with me. **Dir. Gibbs:** I like to know what's happening in my site. A thaumaturgy-linked mine collapse is a major concern. //Dr. Weller shakes his head as he trudges forward.// **Dr. Weller:** Anomalous phenomena slowing down here my foot, it still feels like a magnet for oddities. **Dir. Gibbs:** At the very least, we didn't detect any further compromise in the surrounding parts of the mine. A small-scale detonation, a collapse at the end of a single tunnel. **Dr. Weller:** The vibrations from the collapse weren't enough to stir anything, were they? **Dir. Gibbs:** //[She shakes her head]// OROGENESIS would've pinged us if it did. Seems like the thaumaturgical blast was too weak to set off anything below. **Dr. Weller:** Thank god. We don't need anything crawling outta hell whilst we're on a rescue mission. //Her face has turned to worry. Dr. Weller pauses and glances at her.// **Dr. Weller:** Don't kid with me, Hellen. I know you're worried, but we both know that someone might be down here. **Dir. Gibbs:** I'm more than worried. I think there //is// someone down here. It was a //Way//, Rudy. Someone could've come through it before it fell. //Dr. Weller ducks his head in a nod, though his expression is uncertain. The two of them pick up their pace.// //As the two walk, Dr. Weller pulls a small map from his hip -- the spot of the collapse marked with a sharpie. He traces his finger along as they travel through the mine. They take a left, a right, cross a mesh bridge built over a gap and pass old equipment and minecart rails. Every once and a while, Dir. Gibbs reaches over to the wall and flips a heavy switch -- turning on old lights with a heavy THUNK!// //They turn a final corner, and find what they're looking for. A few meters down, the ceiling of the tunnel has been partially collapsed -- damaged supports and fallen rock.// **Dr. Weller:** ...We should tread lightly. Dunno how stable all that looks. **Dir. Gibbs:** Indeed. //Dr. Weller approaches the collapse, staring up at the snapped wooden supports -- he squints.// **Dr. Weller:** They look burnt. //Dir. Gibbs, who'd been crouched next to a small gap in the rocks -- seemingly attempting to peer beyond the collapse -- looks up.// **Dir. Gibbs:** Looks like the effects of the Way detonating. Look at the ceiling -- swirl patterns. //She points at the cave roof, Dr. Weller turns up the brightness of his hardhat's light, and it fully illuminates glittering patterns peaking out from some of the boulders and ceiling. Odd, discordant swirls that branch off one another with an ashen glitter.// **Dr. Weller:** Thaumaturgic imprints. Right, right. //From beyond the fallen rocks and broken wood, a quiet groan is heard. Dir. Gibbs and Dr. Weller both jolt, eyes wide.// //Dir. Gibbs crouches by a part in the rocks, and angles her flashlight so that it can somewhat shine into the small gap. Against the dark, she can see scorch marks along the tunnel floor, burned-in runes on the far wall.// //And a battered figure collapsed amongst the dust.// //After a moment of silence, Dir. Gibbs opens and closes her mouth a few times before speaking.// **Dir. Gibbs:** ...Are you okay? //Dr. Weller crouches down next to her, brow knitted in concern and alarm. His hand, pre-emptively, rests against his hip as though prepared to pull a weapon. Dir. Gibbs glances at him warily.// //The figure shifts and sits up slowly. The two can see the shape of two curved horns and a snout in the limited light.// **Unknown:** //...Hello..?// //The voice is a quiet, weak murmur.// **Dir. Gibbs:** Hello. My name is Director Hellen Gibbs, and this -- //She gestures to Dr. Weller, though is unsure if the other can see.// **Dir. Gibbs:** Is Doctor Rudy Weller. Are you okay? Do you know where you are? **Unknown:** I don't. To ah, to both of those? //[There is a pause for a sharp intake of breath]// Something burns. I-- I don't know what. I think I got burned coming in. //There is a pause.// **Unknown:** You said you were a Director? **Dir. Gibbs:** Yes. Is that of significance to you? //Dr. Weller is visibly tense, eyes narrowing.// **Dr. Weller:** //...Gibbs, did it come here on purpose..?// **Unknown:** Yeah. Cause that means you're Foundation. So it worked, holy shit. //[The figure tries to shift, and hisses sharply]// //Ow. Fuck me running --// okay. Okay. Half worked. **Dir. Gibbs:** So you did come to us on purpose. **Unknown:** Yes. I-- I was running. I think? I don't fully remember. Which is concerning. I just know I had to get out of the Library. //Dr. Weller glances at Dir. Gibbs, who simply has her head tilted to the side as she listens. He narrows his eyes, and turns back to the gap in the rocks.// **Dr. Weller:** Why's that? **Unknown:** I don't know. Everything feels... wrong right now. My head hurts. **Dir. Gibbs:** //[She frowns]// Do you know your name? //For a moment, the individual doesn't respond -- before suddenly perking up.// **Unknown:** Yes! Yes, I do. It's Draws. Well, Dino. Then Draws. First and last, that's the words for it. Fi and fir. //[There's a pause]// It's kinda weird. I'm sorry. I don't think I did it right.[[footnote]] Henceforth, within documentation, this individual will be referred to under the temporary designation of "PoI-1027".[[/footnote]] //Dr. Weller huffs in confusion, and glances at Dir. Gibbs.// **Dir. Gibbs:** I've heard weirder. You're alright, dear. //[She briefly chuckles]// Speaking of alright -- you said you were hurt? **PoI-1027:** Yeah. I'm not... good at magic. I messed it up. I think I burnt my arms and back? Been trying not to move much. //[There's an inhale, it's shaky]// Are you gonna-- are you gonna be able to get me out of here? **Dr. Weller:** Our only folks qualified to do that are still a few days out, but we'll… do the best we can in the meantime. **Dir. Gibbs:** We'll keep you safe, okay? Do you know how to use first aid? **PoI-1027:** Yeah, I think so. **Dr. Weller:** Then we're gonna go get you that. Some water, too yeah? //[He looks to Gibbs]// Probably. //PoI-1027 nods.// **Dir. Gibbs:** Sit tight, you'll be okay. [[/div]] ----- Weller wipes his brow, as he hauls open the door and exits the mine, "Why does it feel like it's //always// dragons, with this Department? Is there a correlation I'm missing?" the door shutters shut behind him with a heavy slam, and they walk away from the door and towards a small wooden shack. Weller slips a key off his hip, and opens it up -- the old door creaking in protest of their entrance. "I think in this case, it's coincidence, Rudy," Gibbs replies, hanging her hardhat on a wall-mounted rack. "I don't think fi meant to end up underground." "Maybe," the old man sighs in response. Gibbs simply hums quietly to herself, opening the small closet space to stow her high-vis vest. "I dunno how to feel about all that, though. Feels strange." "A little, but I’m curious." Weller sighs, "Yeah, well, if you end up back down there be damned careful. We know nothing of that PoI." She can hear the tense sort of annoyance in his voice. "I know, I know.” Gibbs sighs, “You can get back to work, Rudy. I saw you were handling integrating some new volunteers when the change of plans hit." she glances at him, extending a hand to take and hang his vest, "my schedule for the day is clear, anyways." She hears Weller grunt as he slips off the high-vis and hands it off to her, seeming to consider her words for a few moments. "Bah, I'd almost rather deal with dragons over interns." he jokes, "But yeah, yeah. I will. But—" he pointedly pokes her shoulder, "—//you// better keep your guard up. Be careful." "You don’t have to lecture your own Director, Rudy.” Gibbs chuckles as the man heaves a mockingly dramatic sigh, though it's all in good nature. She leads the way out of the storage shack, and strides away from the mine's heavy doors, across the grass and gravel towards the containment fence that keeps the entrance fully sealed. The Director presses her palm to a scanner. It hums to life, before the fence rumbles open and allows the two departure. They cross the Site's lot over towards the building itself -- one that sits nestled in the gap between two mountains, with an overgrown swamp and a lone road as its sole neighbors. Gibbs swipes her keycard, holds the door open for Weller, and they both slip inside. Site-898 is primarily a white-walled research facility, small in scale (by Foundation standards, that is) but they've done work to make it feel like home. After giving a nod to one of the few members of Site security, Gibbs passes by colorful posters and doors to offices propped open with (non-anomalous) rock samples. Windows let sunlight filter in, reflecting off display cases of various minerals and crystals from around the world.   Weller peels off when she enters the Site's Habitation Sector; a two story space that looked akin to a hotel's open lobby, which holds host to the Site's population of roughly 100 staff. The roof curves into a dome above her head, a few windows shine light down onto the foyer of the second floor that rims the room. The center fixture of it all was a behemoth crystal -- deep and glittering black, with conical spiked protrusions. A scale from the deceased [https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/scp-8007 SCP-8007] instance of Plosky Tolbachik. It sits as part of a fountain, and she catches the glimpse of Dr. Lindsey's much-beloved koi fish swimming happily inside amidst bits of foliage. Well-socialized little critters, currently being spoiled with treats via two researchers sat on the fountain's rim. She greets them, and others milling around the space, with a small nod or wave as she passes through towards the cafeteria. She gets a concerned look from one when she slips a first-aid kit from the wall and stores it under her arm, as she passes into the mess hall. It's a quick in-and-out sort of trip. She asks the nearest cook for a to-go container, and filled it with various bits of food. Some rotisserie chicken, mashed potatoes, broccoli, and corn. She throws a plastic fork in there, tucks a water bottle into her pocket, and it's back into the August heat to re-enter the Red Brook Mine. Gibbs re-opens the gate, dons her PPE, and tugs open the door. The air of the mine is far cooler than the frankly sweltering outside, and she's quite glad for that. It's a five minute walk through tunnels, over gaps, in the sprawling mine -- before Gibbs returns to that collapsed dead end. Evidently, her footsteps had been quite audible, as she sees three blue eyes shining back at her from through the gap in the rock. "You're back," she hears Draws remark, the corners of the three eyes upturned. "Brought a first aid kit, some food and water. Let's see if I cram it through, or if I'm gonna be sending it in pieces." Gibbs replies, sitting down by the collapse. The first aid kit does, in fact, end up being too wide to fit the gap. So Gibbs takes out the bottle of antibiotic, water and medical gauze, passing it into Draws' clawed hand. "All I need to do is clean and bandage them, right?" fi asks quietly, "I've never really gotten burned before." "Rinse with water, dry it, apply the antibiotic and then wrap it." Gibbs replies with a nod, and she hears Draws occasionally hiss as fi does as instructed. After a few moments, Draws starts to talk. "This is a mine, right? I see wooden supports 'n stuff." the words come out slightly strained, as fi works to tend to the burns. "Indeed. It used to be a coal mine, primarily." Gibbs replies, leaning back against the rock. She rests a hand on the to-go container, she can pass it to Draws once fi finishes fixing firself up.    "Is this place in the Appalachians, then?" Now //that// came as a bit of a surprise. Gibbs turns her head, raises an eyebrow, "Pennsylvania, yes. How did you know?" "Well, it's kinda a coin flip," Draws chuckles, a tad sheepish, "coal really only is dug up on the East Coast or the Midwest in America. Which is where I assumed we were." "You have geological knowledge," the woman remarks, brow raising, "intriguing coincidence." "Mm?" "I'm a geologist, as are my workers. This mine sits below Geological Research Site-898." There's a pause, seemingly of shock, before Draws goes, "Wow... okay-- alright," with a certain giddiness tracing fir tone. "That lady didn't lie then." "About what?" "When I was looking for -- for the spell that I used -- I asked a lady behind the checkout for how I control where I go. She said that, sometimes, you don't? But Ways have a -- ha -- //way// with things. Sometimes they take you just where you need to go." "So more than a coincidence," Gibbs smiles. "And more like magic." Draws agrees. "So you've studied the field?" Gibbs tilts her head, even though Draws can't see her. "Yeah! I ah-- I remember studying it in the Library. I don't... think I had a traditional schooling, but I liked wandering around the Stacks and picking up books on it. Did you know the Library has its own deposits?" "I didn't," Gibbs says, interest lining her tone, "can you tell me about them? I've never seen the Library." "Well! The lantern koi will spit up this incandescent liquid every once and a while -- it's like a glass? Silica, probably. And they'll form these bead-y looking stalactites on the undersides of shelves and ceilings. They glow like they have fireflies inside them," Draws' voice has come to life -- forgoing the earlier pain and strain, becoming suddenly quite animated. Gibbs smiles softly. As she listens to the other talk, she finds her gaze tracing a rivulet of water that drips down the wall near her. The rainwater from a few days past must finally be working its way down. "There are scales from the Serpent tucked far down below if you know where to look -- they've been fossilized by paper and stone which //looks// really damn weird. The scales are like... all layered? And they've been pressed down by the Library above and cemented into this glittering calcite-type stuff. They're a deep green with a sort of oil-y sheen to em. I wish I could've broken off a piece to take with, but they're super sturdy." Draws’ voice echoes off the mine’s walls, the sounds of shifting feathers indicating fir wings fluttering as fi speaks. "That sounds wonderous," Gibbs hums, "it makes sense that a place as infinite and sprawling as the Wanderers' Library would host not just its own ecosystem, but its own geological processes." The rivulet ends at a puddle carved by erosion, and still she watches the water drip. "Yeah... I wish I could've explored more," Draws' voice dips down in volume, becoming a bit smaller. Gibbs is pretty sure fi shrinks inwards, too. A tilt of the head, another water droplet hits the puddle. "Do you remember now why you left?" She hears a rustling, probably Draws shaking fir head before realizing Gibbs can't see and goes, "No. I just... I know I was scared. Relieved? I'd... done something before I left. Not a bad thing!" Gibbs vaguely sees Draws' waving fir claws in the air, "I did something that... made me feel relieved. But in doing it I don't think I was... safe anymore?" Gibbs listens, making a quiet sound to indicate such, and furrows her brow. The dragon beyond the rocks sounds both confused and... lost. She finds herself fishing a small pebble out from the puddle. "I wasn't safe. So I ran. I think it was part of a plan because I already had the spell to leave. I just... I don't remember." "What do you remember?" Gibbs tilts her head, "about your time in the Library." There's a long pause. Silence broken only once by a droplet of water. "Well, I grew up in there." //Drip.// "Alone?" "No." The response is quick. "I had others." a pause, hesitation, "I don't... I don't think I liked them." "I'm sorry to hear that," Gibbs replies softly, frowning. There's a lapse into silence. She tries to peak a little further into the gap, and sees Draws' gaze is downcast -- face twisted into something that seems equal parts confused, and conflicted. When she straightens up again, she elects to change topics. "I brought you food and water, if you're hungry." She places the smooth, water-shiny pebble onto the to-go container. "Really?" she sees Draws' perk up. "Yup, here--" Gibbs scoops up the container, and holds it up to the gap. A pair of feathered hands, with curved black claws, reaches out and tentatively takes it. "Might've gotten cold, sorry about that." she chuckles lightly. Gibbs smiles a little, when she sees Draws gently pick up the pebble in fir claws, and stares at it. "Oh!" The pebble is slipped into the pocket of a tattered coat, "It's alright! I can fix that," Gibbs is about to ask what that means, before there's a few small flashes of blue-purple light from the gap. The faint smell of smoke. //Right. A dragon.// //"Ohh! Fuck yes I love potatoes,"// she hears Draws' murmuring excitedly as fi opens the container. Gibbs shifts her sitting position, and quiet repacks the first aid kit so she can return it later. She raises her head when she hears Draws shift -- claws scraping against stone. "Thank you -- uh," a pause, "ma'am? What was your name again? You said it earlier but I'm really bad with names." She chuckles, "Hellen Gibbs." "Okay! Alright, alright. And you know mine too, right? Did I tell you about the middle part?" She watches, curiously, as Draws seems to draw firself inwards again. "I don't think you did." Gibbs blinks, tilts her head. "Oh! Well, uh -- I think my... what's the word -- middle name? It's two dashes." The statement is awkward, a touch confused. "Two dashes?" Gibbs echoes, "How'd that happen?" Her eyes briefly flicks over to the puddle again, when an especially large droplet splatters against its surface. "Um. I'm... not sure? It's just sorta on my Library card. Two little dashes. So I assume it's part of my name. Those show your true name, y'know?" she hears Draws' tap fir talons against the rock. A quiet //tink-tink-tink.// "Huh." Gibbs blinks a bit, "interesting." "Yeah I don't know why it's like that either," Draws says sheepishly, "maybe it's just Library-weirdness." "I wouldn't know either," Gibbs chuckles, "but I'll keep that bit in mind." "Alrighty," fi replies, and there's more shuffling before the Styrofoam container appears half-through the hole. "I finished the food you brought." Gibbs takes the container back, "Good, good. I'll be sure to bring you more later, alright? Not gonna let you go hungry down here." "Thank you," Draws murmurs. For a brief moment, Gibbs sees fir eyes drop down, the glinting of fir teeth as fi opens and closes fir mouth a few times. "Do you know how long it'll be?" "Not too long. Maybe three days? Our team is en-route back soon." Gibbs assures, putting her hand on the rock that shelves the gap, "We'll keep an eye on you in the meantime. Do you have anything in there with you? I could probably bring you a thing or two for entertainment." There's a shuffling, "All I've got is my hat, and my clothes. My pockets uuhhh... //whatisinhereholdon--//" even more shuffling. Gibbs hears a quiet clatter. "I've got a pen! And a pebble. I dunno how long that's been there, ooh! Wait! I've got a book. Oh please let this not be a Library book I don't wanna a late charge--" Gibbs tilts her head as she hears paper rustling. "Oop, never mind. False alarm," Gibbs hears Draws pat the book, "this one's mine." "Well that's good," Gibbs nods, "I can bring you some books if you want." Through the gap, she sees Draws perk up. "You said this is a Geological Research Site right? Do you have like... books for that?" "Plenty. Though... they're primarily //textbooks//, so I don't know if those would fit through the gaps. However, I think we have a few pocket-sized field guides, though." Gibbs drums her finger against her leg. "I can bring them the next time I come down." She hears another droplet of water. "That'd be awesome!" Draws claps fir claws together, "I was worried I was gonna go stir crazy down here." fi trails off with a chuckle, before adding on: "Miss Gibbs?" "Mm?" "Can you -- can you stay and talk, too? When you come back?" "Of course." Gibbs smiles softly, and in the low light, through the gaps in the rock, she can see that Draws is too. ----- [[=]] [[div class="modal"]] ++ This file is currently under edit lock by: +++ [[span class="green"]] @@hgibbs@scp.int@@ [[/span]] [[/div]] [[/=]] [[div class="blockquote"]] [[=]] +++ Person of Interest 1027 [[/=]] **PoI Designation:** 1027 **Date of Identification:** 21/8/2011 **Name:** Dino ‐‐ Draws[[footnote]]**Database alert:** Possible semiohazard detected.[[/footnote]] [[span class="green"]] (Adjust for footnote later: Database keeps trying to change the double-dash to an em-dash due to something in the code that's making an error pop up, but it's a double dash.) [[/span]] [[include component:image-block     name=holdingcell.png|     caption=PoI-1027 within Holding Cell B. |     align=right|         width=300px| ]] **Description:** PoI-1027 is a [[span class="green"]]currently unknown[[/span]] draconic humanoid of indeterminate age. [[span class="green"]]Note, this is unconfirmed -- but fi seemed young? [[/span]] PoI-1027's scales are a range of dark purples, with light purple feathers down the back, tail, and on the hands and feet. A series of darker, plate-like scales run down fir body, as well as fir limbs, and PoI-1027 bears two curved horns on the head. The entity is in possession of --two sets of wings, and a fan of feathers upon the tail.-- [[span class="green"]]Three sets of feathered wings,[[/span]] and is capable of flight. [[span class="green"]]Note for later: don't forget apparent fire-breathing, amateur thaumaturgy skills. Mention three eyes, the clear covering on the neck/chest/tail and apparently liquid organ system. I am not a biologist, send a memo to Dr. Souch for some sort of checkup — especially to check fir burns.[[/span]] **Background Information:** [[span class="green"]]PoI-1027 manifested in the Red Brook Mine via a self-created Way on 21/8/2011, and would remain trapped there until freed by MTF Gamma-89 on 24/8/2011. For the period of time in which fi was trapped, Director Hellen Gibbs would take on the primary duty of overseeing fir. (Note, currently unsure how to summarize several off-record conversations, bullet pointing for now) * Fled from the Library, does not remember why. Only remembers fir emotions, blurred images. Has forgotten individuals, too. Knows there was a threat to fir life. * Signs point to possible antimemetic exposure? Over the course of the three days I asked if fir head has cleared -- and fi's told me no, for the most part. Fi has sustained no head injuries * Has surprisingly intricate knowledge of geology, claims to have undergone schooling in the Library. Judging by the talks we had (and a bit of for-fun quizzing and discussion on my part) fir knowledge seems apt towards college level. * Generally well mannered, appears non-hostile. Curious, excited, lost.   * Currently in Holding Cell B of the Containment Sector (Basement Floor) [[/span]] [[div id="blink-bar"]] **Course of Action:**     [[/div]] [[/div]] ----- Gibbs has had the PoI file half-screen split with the general Foundation database for more hours than necessary. She rubs the side of her face with a sigh, feeling that growing pit in her stomach once again. Dripping water rings in her ears. Containment. It was looming on her mind like some horrible miasma. There was something cosmically cruel in knowing that Draws had came to them for protection, for safety -- to escape from something. To hear that and know that fir likely destination //now// was a containment cell for god knows how long rose a guilt in Gibbs' chest that she wasn't used to. She thinks of the excitement in fir voice, that intense passion -- hell, a relevant one to the very Site she commands. //"Ways have a -- ha -- way with things. Sometimes they take you just where you need to go."// Gibbs lowers her head. //Fi doesn't deserve this.// But there is a sprinkle of hope. An idea. If she can pull it off, then just maybe-- She's torn from her thoughts by a loud knock on her office door. Gibbs raises up her head, "Come in," and in steps Dr. Sarah Lindsey -- an old woman, and an old friend -- Geophysics Chair. "Ah, Sarah. Is there something wrong?" "Nah, me 'n Rudy were just wondering where you were. Remember those dinner plans we made?" Lindsey hums, she gestures to the clock. Gibbs stares at it, racks her brain, and remembers it's about two hours //from// said dinner plans. "Ah... shoot, right. I'm just," Gibbs pauses, glances at her screen, sighs, "struggling a little with Draws' PoI file." "Struggling with what part? Containment?" The statement was meant to be a joke, but the way Gibbs frowns makes her tilt her head, "You'd figure that to be the easy part!" "It's not. We barely contain living things here -- a few, sure, but to date we've never gotten anything //sapient// in the Site." Gibbs murmurs, "Fi's a sapient humanoid -- once everything's filed in full, fi'll end up shipped off to Site-17 or something to never see the light of day again." It makes Lindsey pause, a concern bubbling in her features -- taken aback by her Director's apparent dismay. "You're upset about this." Is all she finds herself able to say, brow furrowed. "Of course I am," comes the response, "there's a bright young mind down there in that holding cell-- someone who could have a future. A future //here.//" //Fi fled to us.// The added thought makes Gibbs hang her head in silence. It feels all so naive of her, but her site -- her //Department// -- has rarely dealt in things with thought. Rocks typically don't come with as many quandaries on the conscious. "I've been combing through the database for the past few hours -- looking for something, //anything// that may keep fir out of a cell." "Any luck?" Lindsey asks weakly. Part of her hoped so. And to her surprise, Gibbs inhales, composes herself, and nods. "Yeah, one thing. Come look." Gibbs gestures to Lindsey to come over to her desk. The woman closes the door behind her and slips over, positioning herself to look over her Director's shoulder and at the computer monitor. "[https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/scp-7629 SCP-7629] -- The Sky Keepers, or more simply, 'Droganians'." She gestures to the file, before paging down and downloading an attached document. "The Foundation found an underground city of dragon people in the late 90s, and made a political arrangement with them." Lindsey blinks rapidly, "What in the Tolkien..?" "I think the Roundtable Agreement might be our new friend's lucky break." She raises an eyebrow, "Why's that?" and Gibbs looks up at Lindsey, her solemn face breaking into a grin. "There's an exchange program." [[div class="document"]] [[=]] [[image roundtable.png]] //THE ROUND TABLE AGREEMENT / SCP-7629 PROTOCOL// [[/=]] //[...]// //Droganian volunteers may be integrated into Free Port Nexuses and willing Foundation facilities as a part of integration and exchange to aid in their re-incorporation into the modern anomalous world. These individuals, granted they do not breach Veil protocols, will not be subjected to usual Foundation containment methods.[[footnote]] In the event of a breach of Veil protocols, the Foundation is given purview over any prisoner granted they inform the Dragoon’s Circle of actions taken.[[/footnote]] Integrated Droganians are to be recognized as having the same rights and protections as anomalous humanoids within the relevant Nexuses.// //Volunteers desiring integration into the Foundation need either sufficient education, or are to apprentice under pre-existing employees. Similarly, they are required to pass screenings typical of Foundation hiring channels before employment can be officially accepted.// //[...]// [[/div]] Lindsey scans the section of the document once, twice, head tilting -- but a look of intrigue is steadily growing. "Slight hitch. Draws doesn't fully match with being a Droganian. Too many wings, an extra eye. They seem quite physiologically diverse, but this might be pushing it." She glances over. "A bit, though it looks like some have feathers. Regardless, you know how it is with thaumaturgy, right?" Gibbs gives her a sly look, "especially something as unpredictable as a //failed// spell that has quite the backfire. We could simply... hand wave fir strangeness?" Lindsey's brow shoots up, and she finds herself giving a half-manic giggle, "Hellen! Isn't that falsifying information?" "I prefer to call it //'proposing a hypothesis'.//" Gibbs hums back, "If we fudge some things, we can conclude in the final POI file that Draws is Droganian, augmented by fir passage through the collapsing Way, and I can invoke this section of the Roundtable Agreement in fir defense." "Has Draws stated what fi may be on record?" Gibbs shakes her head, "Only off-record, and that fi doesn't know." "Well!" Lindsey claps her hands, "Then I suppose we have good news for fir, mm?" The Director's face brightens. "A whole lot of it, actually." ------ [[div class="modal"]] [[=]] ++ Submit edit and upload file? [[collapsible show="Confirm" hide="Upload Successful!"]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:id-card |css=-- |photo=draws |level=2 |name=Dino ‐‐ Draws |dept=Geology |position=Jr. Researcher |id-number= 1027-89821 |expiry=05/2020 ]] "Welcome to the team," Director Gibbs' voice is professional, but fi can hear an underlying joy. The card is held gently in a set of claws, as Draws stares down at it. It's hung around fir neck by a lanyard, and fi turns it over in fir talons a few times. Fi looks at fir name, fir own face staring back, then up at Gibbs -- and smiles brightly. The relief is palpable. [[/collapsible]] [[/=]] [[/div]]
amnesia-was-fir-name.title: Amnesia Was Fir Name - SCP Foundation

bloodsandandguns.raw_content:
“I think it’s time you got a change of pace don’t you think? Been a hot minute since you’ve seen field work, hasn’t it?” The voice, slightly chiding in tone, was directed at Gabriel Clef from a small screen present on his desk. Despite the distortion leveled on it to protect the users identity, its southern twang still rang true through its words.

When he had been told his father would make it up to him, Gabriel hardly expected this to be the outcome. Then again, planning around his father had always been like planning for a chance of rain that benefited you; hardly possible, not foolproof worthy to bring an umbrella, and mostly up to the changing of tides.

Gabriel Clef sat fiddling with a stressball, leaning back in the plush leather roller chair as he pretended he really gave a fuck. It wasn’t particularly the safest way to lounge, hes been warned against it but in the comfort of the red and black office there wasnt a soul going to tell him off. The benefits of seniority and status in his position. His eyes flick down to the fidget toy, giving it another squeeze, then up to the screen. The call had been completely out of the blue, as per usual, but when you’re the son of Alto Clef you learn to work on his schedule. Not yours.

The screen bears no emotion, no sign of the larger than life figure on the other end, excepting the flickering of the SCP logo on the screen.

“So how about it?”

——

Samuel Roscharch squints.

“A change of scenery?”

“Yes Samuel. I think you’re in high need of it, and not just that, considering your work here in Area Two has just about been offloaded to me, I don’t see why not. Additionally, you have 180 vacation days you have failed to cash-in, which you can still make use of at any time you deem necessary. Whens the last time you had a genuine peek at the outside world outside of work hours?

Samuel sighs, carding a hand through his head of black hair, strands of white interspersed amongst it from the toll stress has taken on him, as he stares fruitlessly down at the report paper he’s supposed to be grading. The words have bled together a long time ago, a mixture of official jargon and foundation doublespeak that would lull less experienced personnel to sleep. That was somewhat of its purpose; these papers were important after all, couldn’t have just anyone understanding what exactly they pertained to. Sometimes Samuel had the thought that half of these papers didn’t even understand themselves.

With his new position, he was getting recognised. That was clear, yes, but by god did the paperwork keep on stacking up. Where he had been able to slice through 20 reports with ease, he now saw an ever climbing pile of tasks in his inbox tray, a hydra where every report equalled another three more and kept him chained to his desk, that insistent thought in the back of his head repeating he could only ever take a break when it was all done.

He looks up at the evidence board in front of him, lines crossing over pictures, coffee stained papers and post-it notes. Maybe SAM was right. The dang thing just about ran autonomously now, in regards to answering his teams inquiries. His social inbox was quiet, only devoted to these more administrative papers that bore all the importance of any document. Samuel Roscharch had less requirement than ever to interact with his fellow man, which suited him just fine all things considered. Yet there was still a nagging for a genuine push to do so; as the saying goes all work no play makes Jack a dull boy. And judging by stats, with a cursory side eye to the other screen, he was in sore need of it.

Sam waves a dismissive hand to his main monitors digital assistant, as pinching his nose, he squints at the letters on the paper he’s reading through.

“Fine. Set me up on a field mission that you deem fits my ability criteria.”

“Affirmative leave it to me!”

——

In two different offices, 200 km from each other, a memo is received on their respective computers, one being eyed with casual boredom, to be perused sporadically as per his norm when the mood struck him, the other clicked open immediately and several tabs brought up automatically. His computer system detects and highlights relevant information and documentation. Their respective digital friends spoke of it in their own ways, informing them verbally of the necessary TLDR.

“You will be going on a two person mission to investigate a company that seems to be using anomalous tech to further their company proceeds. Due to our lack of jurisdiction in the Gulf, you will be going undercover. Attached to the dossier you will find your fly date, and your allowance. And, ah yes. Your partner for this mission will be..”

—-

“Clef.”

“Samuel.”

“Don't you think that getup is a bit much?”

Samuel Roscharch squints. His flight was a long one, and he’s not used to the bright night lights of the cities glare. He's used to the dimmer light sensitive bulbs of the facility, which he realises weren’t as bright as he once judged them to be if these are so grating on the eyes. Here Gabriel is, in his usual (at least for Gabriels case) bright outfit, consisting of white jeans and a prussian blue hawaiian shirt with a leaf pattern. Roscharchs eyes flick over the loud outfit, the LC500 Lexus he's leaning against, and Gabriels shit eating grin he's giving Roscharch, and can’t help but express some doubt on whether the guy had fully read the brief or if he’s just here for vacations sake. He sure looks the part. The company full paid mission fund does come in handy for drinks after all.

Gabriel chides him. “Someone didn’t read the dress memo. You look like someones white collar accountant.” Compared to Gabriel there was none of the flamboyance and color present in Roscharch’s outfit. Dressed in a brown jacket tossed over a work shirt and corduroy dress pants, a patterned tie and a standard issue belt, he was someone you’d pass over in the street, eyes sliding over him in a crowd without a second thought. While Clef looked like he’d walked straight out of a magazine page, Roscharchs garb was more ruffled, the blame being his far from peaceful night on the plane. He never was the best sleeper.

“I did read the memo, it said to fit in and be discrete. Kind of what I was going for.”

With a hoist, he throws his dented case and duffle bag into the open back of the car alongside Gabriel’s suitcases, slamming it shut and then making his way over to the right side.

“Yeah well where we’re going that drab little outfit of yours will NOT make you “fit in”. Or “be discrete”. Just saying!” Gabriel swings into the drivers seat, turning the key and revving the engine. It roars to life, giving a purr that makes him grin. “I managed to get a bit of a change to accommodation.”

“By bit of a change you mean upping our expenditures.   

“I wouldn’t say that. I’d say it’s a more.. considerate use of our funds. To fit the clientele we’re dealing with.”

“Fine. Where are we going anyway.”

Roscharch shifts, buckling in and checking the glove and shades compartments, as Gabriel pulls out and onto the main road.

“Oh you’ll see!”

——

“And you’ll be upgraded to an executive suite immediately. Though do note it is a smoking floor.”

“What does that mean for the room?”

The entire lobby was warmly lit by the resplendent glow of the 300 crystal chandelier hanging above the room, the walls a tangle of repeating geometric patterns the eye easily got lost in. People talk in small groups scattered across the tiled marble floor while a pianist plays on the grand piano standing in the lobby. Gabriel leans on the counter, talking to the well groomed young man manning the lobby desk, his reflection catching in the mottled gold shield behind it.

“Well it means you’ll get a living room, separate bathroom and a balcony along with the current accommodation.

“See what did i tell you?” Gabriel turns his head. “Upgrade.”

Samuel squints at him, hand squeezing the sash of his duffle bag. He’s not used to this. He just wants to get to his room and set up the necessary provisions and leech off the wifi for a while as he scours the already thoroughly thumbed through brief. The plane trip has left him exhausted enough. He scowls.

“We’ll just need your company ID, sir.”

“Wait what? My ID?”

“Yes sir you see as part of the discount and upgrade we have to see any identification of your employment with the company.”

Gabriel blinks and bend down to rummage through the duffel bag next to him. Shit shit shit. Shit!! Shit!! It’s not under the folded outerwear, or the pocket with the magazines, definitely isn’t in the compartment with his toiletries, and scraping the side only brings up a few errant condoms. No ID. Sam watches him somewhat bemused.

“I don’t have it on me. I’m on vacation.”

“Of course. A business card will do then.”

“They don’t give out business cards. I’ve never had this issue before. Look, I’ve booked here before just pull my profile up from last time I booked, it should be there."

“Of course sir let me just check.”

Gabriel’s nails tap impatiently on the marble desk, eying up the company around them. Its mostly a mix of people that, like Gabriel had implied earlier, were on the higher side of life, if not apparent from their tailored fitted clothing, and well maintained figures. There’s the occasional tourist family, outliers for their pack of bags, bright artificial colors and corny novelty t-shirts that don’t toe the line between post-irony and simplification (an important distinction from the bourgeoisie version of those sort of things) but they’re few and far between. From what Gabriel can see, nobody of note that he needs to keep an eye on is present.

The receptionists tanned fingers tap over the keys of the keyboard, eyes flicking over the screen.

“I’ve checked, and while we have your passport, I’m afraid we don’t have your company ID sir.”

Gabriel’s voice raises, a slight scoff on his tone as he inclines his head. “This is fucking bullsh-“

“Sir I’m afraid its hotel policy-“

“Yes I KNOW its hotel policy. Totally get what you’re saying here. I’m saying this is new to me. This hasn’t happened to me before, and if this is the route we’re picking then be confident in the fact i’m never booking with you, again.”

The receptionist looks up from his computer, his dark brown eyes meet Gabriel’s amber ones. A look dares him to call his bluff. That he double dog dares him. The receptionist decides he doesn’t like his odds.

“I’ll go check with my manager sir, one moment.”

He’s gone for a few moments, disappearing behind a wall. When he returns, stoic faced as usual but to the watchful eye a bit more of a crease in his other perfectly content composure. “I’m terribly sorry sir. No need to worry about all of this. Your papers are in order.”

“No worries. Do you mind if I get your name so i can send you them later? Just for you to make sure, iron everything out so we don’t have this problem in future.” Gabriel’s body language relaxes, giving him a wry smile as the man goes a shade paler.

“Its really not necessary.”

“No no i insist. For your records, of course.”

“Uh.. Mohammed Shakif, sir.”

“Well Mohammed, expect an email your hotels way in i’d say.. five to seven business days. Tops. And trust me you’ll know when it comes.”

Mohammed gulped, staring straight ahead while the pair carted their luggage past him into the mahogany hallway with the four elevators.

——

They arrive on the 29th floor of the hotel.

The first thing they both notice walking out into the hallway is the slight smell of nicotine, causing Roscharch to wrinkle his nose as they walk through the wooden paneled halls, shoes quiet on the white carpeted floor. The doors are blue, little side tables with lamps and phones interspersed across the wide hall, dead quiet courtesy of the copious amount of soundproof. What goes on in these suites is the business of the resident, not the hotel, after all. They pay good money to make sure of it.

Samuel had refused concierge — even at the behest of Gabriel for the amount of arm work he would have to do dragging up the provisions and the insistence of “its paid we might as well indulge” — it had been too risky in Sam’s opinion for the bell boys to lay even a finger on the handles of their luggage. But in all actuality, it was moreso he preferred keeping some sort of modicum of connection to being the working man, less removed from all this fancy expenditure and having people wait on doing what you wanted.

Gabriel is already up ahead, pressing the sleek grey keycard with the hotels insignia against the reader as he pushes against the gold handle of the blue door. It opens into a living room, fit with manila painted walls, a wide couch and tv setup, and a minibar counter with a fruit bowl on it. Dark heavy curtains are directly opposite the door, hiding the sparkling view of the city. While Gabriel drops his luggage like a bag of rocks and beelines for the fruit bowl and the drink selection, Roscharch carries his to the master bedroom.

The entire place is carpeted, their steps muffled. With the tug of a cord, the heavy drapes lining one side of the room give way to a tremendous view of the city skylines, skyscrapers embedded with LED lights to give a moving swaying display on their surfaces, the red and yellow blink of cars passing below to the dancing multicolor flashes of nightlight as spotlights comb the sky.

Sam turns his eyes from the exterior and focuses more on the interior. A cupboard stands on his left, two dressing gowns and a safe inside. He narrows his eyes at the beds or well, the one bed in the room.

A queen bed. Roscharch squints at it, and then sighs. Not unexpected per se, just surprising. He had expected two beds, as per norm. But bothering about it would be too much of a hassle; the end of the hall room allows for many benefits and the floor is high and spacious. A good setup if ever. This shouldn’t compromise the mission that much, and the last thing he wants is to be picky on his first mission when requesting specifically for a more suitable setup would raise eyebrows. He might as well call it out now.

 “I’ll take the left side.” Roscharch starts checking the cupboards, finding only a Quran, and a prayer mat. Nothing else.

“Hmm?” Gabriel looks up from where he had been perusing a magazine while chowing down on some fruit, walking over to stand in the doorway and noting the bed, as roscharch stands up from his cupboard check and heads to the bathroom. Oh. A queen bed? That was.. certainly unexpected. Never had that happen before, not on the couple of missions his dad sent him on. Samuel doesn’t seem swayed by it at least, and Gabriel wonders quietly what he must have thought about it, as he hears Roscharch click on the lights and the marble clatter of the the tank lid beimg lifted from the tank. God this guy is weird.

“Alright then. I’ll take the other side. No need to get too cuddly then!”  

 Roscharch rolls his eyes as he places the tank lid back ontop of the toilet, unwrapping the soap to wash his hands. He calls out to Gabriel.

“Can you get the bag in the left compartment of my duffle bag?”

  “Can’t you do that yourself?”  

 “It’ll take you all of five seconds!”  

 Gabriel sighs, as he stoops to open the bag, if Roscharch is giving him permission, he might as well peruse. The guy.. is packed to the fucking nines. Jesus christ this thing is full of bulky items. He pulls out the nondescript black bag, making his way over and placing it on the marble sink countertop and leaning against the wall, arms crossed as Samuel wordlessly unzips it and starts rummaging inside, taking out nondescript black cameras and placing them on the countertop, he counts six.  

 “Seriously? You’re kind of overdoing it on the security, Sam. I mean Jesus Christ we’re working for a foundation with the motto that secures, contains, and protects, but no need to outfit this place like Fort Knox.”

  “Better safe than sorry.”

“Yeah but six?”  

 Samuel starts unpeeling the double sided tape on the back, setting the small paper backings to the side as he clicks them all on, one after the other. Once done, he switches his phone to an app, bringing up the camera and panning it over the room. He catches Gabriel in the picture, who gives the camera a sarcastic grin. Once Roscharch lowers it, Clef moseys on over, taking a peek at what Sam is doing on his phone.

“Taking pictures already of our cute rendezvous away from the facility is certainly a first.”   “No. I’m doing a panoramic view of the room, so I can note the full image for checking if there’s any discrepancies later. SAM catalogues everything in there, including the ostentatious prick leaning agains the door.”

Watching over Sams shoulder, the image loads for a bit before turning black, a separate application creating a digital render of the room, which Sam is using to circle certain areas and place models in. After a bit of thinking, the thing brings up stats, recommending plans of action and efficiency levels.
  “You mean the handsome blonde son of a gun, don’t you?”

  “No. I meant what the application wrote out.” 

 Sam taps the screen, bringing it back to the panoramic original view. Tapping Clefs image in the photo blurs him, and the words “OSTENTATIOUS PRICK” show up on the screen. Gabriel squints.

“You might want to bug check your software Sam, seems to be running below par”  

 “Already did, it’s running at 98.7% efficiency.”  

 “Well it’s telling lies.” 

 “SAM has been anything but a liar.”

 The machine outputs a list of location suggestions for the cameras for the best coverage, registering them all as online and cataloguing the details of the room. Sam picks up a handful of them, moving to the far left of the bathroom to start giving them plastic covers that match the shade of the wall as he continues the conversation with clef, their voices echoing slightly in the enclosed space.

 “Oh come on now. You’ve used that thing to pretend to be you and blow off everyone who doesn’t come bearing gifts and good fortune to your emails front door office. That doesn’t sound like anything but a liar.”  

“It’s not lying, it’s a convenient use of its function. Some people take offense to being answered so candidly by a robot.”  

“You don’t say.” 

 “It helps work efficiency, wasn’t that something you’ve always encouraged? I’m hardly the most sociable person.”  

“There’s something called the skill of learning to manipulate the masses..” 

 “Something that I won’t personally be employing.”  

 Gabriel watches Roscharch bustle about the room, setting them up. He turns his attention to the toiletries on the countertop, inspecting a bottle of lotion that tells him that removal of the luxury item will result in a pretty pricey 200 QAR or 85 USD charge to his card. Sheesh. He looks up as Roscharch moves past him back to the master bedroom, and starts repeating the process of the panorama, and Gabriel sighs. This will take forever, knowing Sam he will want every single cubic inch secure before he starts even considering going out, and Gabriel is more about fieldwork in you know, the field, than whatever B.S. Roscharch is dealing with in all these camera bugs and motion triggers and whatnot.

“Do you HAVE to do this with everything?” 

 “yes, among other things.”

“What’s …left to do?”

 “Well.”  

With a grunt Roscharch stands up from where he had been placing yet another camera bug near the bed, tired eyes meeting Gabriels as he fiddles with the remaining devices in his hand as he answers.

  “First, I’ve got to get these bugs set up. Audio too, for this room and the dining area, as well as the hallway. Motion detectors are online, at least from what I’ve got running right now, the 36 hour battery life should keep us in the know, so to speak. Then I need to collect data from spoofing wifi networks and follow up on some of the leads they gave me and..”

Gabriel can feel his eyes closing just hearing that long list. “BLAH BLAH BLAH. Look. Samuel. Saaammmy.” He makes his way over, casually leaning an arm over him as he talks, leaning into him. “How about this. We do something FUN for a change. Get little ol killjoy out into the big city. We’re in fucking Qatar of all places! In the fucking Ritz no less!” Samuel tenses slightly, stiffening under the friendly gesture as Gabriel keeps talking. Clef knows if he stops then his overactive mind will stutter and short circuit, so the best way to deal with it is to overwhelm the stream of consciousness.

“So here’s what we’ll do. We’ll go out to a club, ok? From there, get contacts, information, drinks, and then we’ll settle in for the long haul! Sound good?”  

Rosharch looks away. “I don’t know, I’m not really a nightlife guy.”   

“You don’t have to really be a nightlife guy to do it. Besides, won’t do any harm, you can probably spoof a few contacts and identities off the hotshots there while I work on getting more “on the ground” intelligence so to speak. Ok? It’ll only be one night.”  

 “I…”

  Samuel’s still on the fence. Gabriel can see it in the way hes fidgeting with the cameras and the way his jaw is tightening, taken offguard by Clefs blatant disregard for his personal space.. Hes pulling a long face. It just won’t do at all. Clef needs action. Clef needs city, and not to deal with the whims of this guy. Clef decides to pull out his trump card, talking softly.

“Samuel.. Please? Come on. You’re my partner for this mission, I’m fine doing it alone, but if I can’t have you around, then who will watch my back? You'll be my eyes in the sky. Come oon. Live a little. ”  

That got him. Samuels breath hitches as he squeezes the cameras tighter. Hes so used to watching from the distance and now Clef has two hands on his shoulders and is shifting him closer to the deep end. Clef watches the cogs work in his brain, the thought process as he weighs pros and cons,gaze narrowing and eyebrows furrowing, as he comes to a decision. His frown deepens for a moment before he relaxes, nodding curtly.

“Alright. Fine. But you have to stay where I can see you.” 

 “Alright alright mr paranoid.”   

“I’m serious.”  

“I know.”

——

Roscharch is not sure if he regrets agreeing to this or not, but he's pretty sure its the latter. His eyes trace over the crowd, a mass of colour and movement and sound. Gabriel meanwhile, feels the rush of life around him and grins.

The place Gabriel picked is a rooftop club which Gabriel assured Sam “was a lot tamer than the others.” Roscharch can't tell. With all the people dancing on the open multicolored lit dance floor in front of the raised DJ station, it seems plenty rowdy enough. Then again he wasn’t a person particularly given to this side of life, so how should he know?

Sitting at the bar that’s backlit through the hundreds of artful, multicolored drink bottles sitting on the shelves, his hands tap at the tinted glass table. He looks over at Gabriel. Gabriel is busy scanning the crowd while he waits to get the barkeeps attention, probably scouting for notables. He always had a way with remembering faces. It’s what made him such a good people person, after all.

Sam eyes turn to the city skyline. You can see the coast from here, the resplendent coloured buildings scraping the sky as they glow, some of them changing hues or writing words on them. It reminds him of the way the crystals in the caves glowed in the dark pitch of the cave, a world away. Hes never been one for homesickness but surrounded by the new he feels a pang of desire for the old, for the known. Surrounded by people, he feels more on edge than hes been in a while.

Gabriel leans on the bar, addressing the man behind the bar. “I’ll have your blood and sand, shaken not stirred, while looking at a bottle of grey goose, and god help you if the orange is the artificial kind.”

The man squints, calculates that in his head, and then gives a curt nod. There have been stranger requests. He’s not questioning it. He turns to Sam.

"And for you sir?"

“Soju.”

 “I’m afraid we don’t serve that here sir.” 

 “Seriously? Soju?” Gabriel chides him. “That’s pretty goddamn tame.”  

“Look, I’m not the best of drinkers. Unlike you, Mr. Five Shots and a kombucha.”  

“Ohhh that’s bullshit. That’s bullshit right there!” Gabriel pokes him. “Didn’t have a problem with it in the past..”  

“That’s the thing. In the past.” 

 “Come oooon Sam. One drink won’t hurt. What happened to “fitting in?” 

 Sam frowns. He turns his gaze to the bartender, who offers him a small smile and clears his throat. 

 “If I may suggest.. perhaps a blue lagoon would suit you?” 

 “…What’s in it?”

“Vodka, curaçao, and lemonade, sir.”  

“Sure. Whatever.”

  “See! There you go sam! Lighten up a little, you got it!”  

One drink later and it had helped to lighten both of their mood and loosen their tongues, if a little. As the first rounds worked their magic and the sound of the music beat a steady rhythm into everything, a more casual conversation developed.

“See, I don’t get your whole deal with randomly testing people. What the hell was that drink order from earlier?”  

“It’s not so much testing as randomly deciding to mess with people. There's a lot of people out there that lack boundaries, complacent to jump sit and stay if you act like you're in charge. I'm testing that instinct. Didn't exactly order him to do that."

"Still. That's quite the gambit to play."

"You knooow sam. Maybe i'm just really picky about my favourite drinks. Have you considered that?"

"No. Why on earth would I consider it?"

"Future reference. Trust me, one of these days you and me have GOT to try some of them, I know some really fanatical ones. You've heard of the Corpse Reviver, but have you heard of the Red Seal of Valhalla?"

"These sound like skips nicknames if I'm being dead honest."

"Moot point. Telling you now sam, chug one of those and you'll be feeling like a legend in not time."

Their rather spirited conversation is interrupted by the elevator door opening across the bar. Gabriel looks over, gets a good look at who's coming out of it, and perks up, straightening as he leans to the side to get a better look. He finally recognizes someone of importance, someone of note. His eyes move past Roscharch, focusing on her.

She’s walking in the club, the elevator closing behind her. Tanned immaculate skin, long dark wavy hair, a white diamond choker and earrings, and a black dress. Her posse of girlfriends, all dressed as fashionably resplendent as her, chatter and laugh amongst each other, tapping on their phones, passing glances over the company to gauge how full this club was, adjusting their hair. They too are checking for people of interest, but in the way that’s common for club goers.

They say hellos to club goers that approach them, exchanging small talk and laughs before most of them head towards an empty half circle couch, sitting down and resuming the conversation. One of them breaks away to head to the bar. Gabriel elbows Sam.

“That’s her.”  

“That’s who?”  

“Noor Salim. She’s the daughter of one of the CEOs connected to Cortex.”  

Sam attempts to turn to look at her, and receives a hard elbow in the side.  

“Don’t make it too obvious! …Was she looking over here?”  

“Yes? Why.”

“Good.”

“Why do you ask?”  

“Just play along, okay?”  

They resume their conversation, Gabriel a bit more animated perhaps than before, smiling and gesturing as they jump from topic and topic. Talking between them has always been easy, the ebb and flow always continuing it on. More drinks are ordered, and drunk. Sam nearly forgets the girl as they get into yet another discussion about what defines “freedom” and what defines “waste of time” until one of the girls from Noor’s table gets up and approaches the bar. As she orders the drinks, she turns to Gabriel.

“Couldn’t help but notice you from across the club. What brings you here?"

Gabriel turns to her, raising his hand and waving it vaguely. "Taking a week or three off of work. Company can shove it for all i care, GOD does it feel nice to be out."

She nods. "Uggh tell me about it. Some of the guys at my work, SO hungup on themselves couldn't tell their heads from their asses with half the repackaged shit they spit out."

"Yup, definitely know the type. It's a ruthless field.."

The bartender comes over. She leans forward, giving him a smile.

"Yeah seven cosmo's pleaaase.Thanks!'

Did you know that the cosmopoli-"

“Cosmopolitan was popularized by Madonna? Yeah I know."

“You’re funny. Didn’t think anyone would be able to beat me to the punch on that.”  

“Better than a martini. Helps to know your drinks.”  The girl lets out a snicker. She gives him an incline of the head, as the bartender makes the drinks. She's interested now, Gabriel knows. First impressions like these are crucial, and he's played it safe and savvy. Can't give too much to make her think he's over-enthusiastic, or not enough to make her think he's one of those dry white collars.

"You know i was just saying this to my friend over here. If you're looking for dedication to the job, he's all that and more." That gets a laugh out of her. At Sams expense sure, but Sam will understand. Sam rolls his eyes, taking another swig of his drink and saying nothing.

"But lets talk less work and more party. I’ve got to say the clubbing scene isn’t anything compared to Berlin.”  

“Lol you're soo right. You seem to know your party spots. What club in Berlin?” 

“Uhh.. well there was a couple. But the one that stuck out to me the most was..ah what was it the Vundabar? Berghain? yes.” 

Her jaw drops. Her eyebrows raised, before with a light laugh she leans closer to him. “Oh my god, the Berghain?? The Berghain?"

"Unless I developed a stammer or heard myself wrong, yes, I one hundred percent mean the Berghain. Never had a problem getting in."

"Wow. Now that's a story."

The bartender passes the drinks to the girl, she smiles, bids Gabriel adieu, and heads back to the table, handing them out and talking to them. A few of the girls look over at Gabriel, and then go back to discussion. Gabriel doesn't need to turn to know. He smiles, swirling his drink and then downing it.

"Hook line and sinker, Sam. Hook line and sinker. Just wait."

He doesn't have to wait long. Samuel isn’t so much focusing on the conversation anymore as tapping on his phone because soon enough, Gabriel is approached by three girls, keeping close to each other as they start asking him questions. Noor watches from the table, sprawling back against the seats and idly chewing on a toothpick. Eventually they ask him to come over and continue the conversation. Gabriel is happy to oblige.

Sam's not invited to the table with them. That suits him just fine, probably wouldn’t have gone anyway, and he chooses to tactfully ignore that theres still a bit of him hurt by the fact this wasn’t something he was offered beforehand. He starts searching for medieval executions.

First meeting someone who's prestigious and making them like you, when they're used to having people like them and it always being a one way street, is sort of like having a job interview, and there is absolutely no difference except the scene they use to do it. They ask for your experience. A rough CV. Through questions they prod you about your character traits. And then in some mystical unspoken way come to a decision on whether you're it or not.

It is often that a person is underqualified. It's hard not to feel intimidated. There is the occasion where you're overqualified; know too much and the opponent can feel hostile, threatened, it's human nature. Gabriel however is able to balance the middle line, letting the girls talk, measuring the tempos and tones, playing the perfect foil and comrade.

He's able to answer their questions, say things in a way familiar to their style of language. He's cordial. He's devilish. While Noor is generally more stoic, ignoring and addressing her girl friends to test him, soon enough they're talking to each other too, about the ways they subtly poke at others for fun, about stories of parties and late night hijinks.

Sam searches up recipes in his phone and watches how to make a seafood bisque.

He’s kind of forgotten about the mission. The alchohol makes his head feel dizzy. And then hes nudged as Gabriel passes, arm in arm with that girl and her friends as they look at each other.

“Hey man we’re ditching this place. See me and Noor were talking and the main club scene is kinda overrated. The real money is in house parties. You coming?”

  Sam considers if they want him to say no. He should say no. He could. But a small part of his heart recalls so clear what Gabriel said earlier. They should stick together, right? Sam makes a face, letting out a sigh as he goes to grab his coat.

“I can bring the car round, sure.”

One of the girls looks over him. His demeanour leaves somewhat lacking in clubbing buddies. She voices her thoughts.

“I don’t know if he should..”

Sam squints at her. He isn't helping his case. Gabriel looks between them and clears his throat.
 “Ladies! Ladies, please, someone has to drive me back. Appreciate the sentiment but my hotel is pretty far from here.”   “Or weee could have someone take you back from my place gaaabe.”

“And go to all that bother? Let me be a gentleman and spare you the fuss.”

“Gabe if that story about you in Maldives you told is true I think you’re HARDLY the one to speak on gentlemanship.”

They burst into laughter, continuing to talk in this matter as they take the elevator down. They're already on private knowledge. Sam furrows his brow, to stop himself from rolling his eyes at their nonsensical blather. He has a feeling its going to be a long night.  
—

Out of the city, past the streets. The streets give way to backroads, then open roads, and finally, gates. Gates that lead into the places where the real rich come to play. Lots of land, massive and sprawling and lavish, houses that sit on an island all of their own. The club music is following here too, on the radio.  Past long big driveways lined with desert and palm trees, they finally pull up on a geometric modern mansion, lights flashing from the windows, people partying on balconies, cars parked wherever. This. THIS is where the real party is.

If Sam had to describe it, it had all the rowdiness of a high school get together that he was never invited to, wrapped up in the lavish bows and finery that gem and oil money can buy you. Catching up with the group, he walks in and-

Ho. Lee. Fuck.

The music is amplified, seeming to jostle his bones. The open floor layout isn’t as crowded as the club from before, but that doesn’t mean it isn’t rife with action. A bar higher, if some of the way partygoers are dressed is anything to base off of. The entire place is tinged purple and red, people yelling and laughing over the din as waiters walk through the crowd passing small drinks and treats over adult movie stars lounging in the laps of suited men. The air seems colored too, a slight fog filling the air and giving it a dreamlike feel from the hookahs some of the party is using while sitting on divans, talking business.

The kitchen island serves as a bar and a la carte table, with plates decked with proper food, and other delicacies being available. Hell, Sam thinks he sees small vials of meth on the table, for anyone who's feeling particularly ballsy. Gabriel lets out a low whistle and then laughs. Sam can’t hear what he says over the din. He asks him to repeat it.

“WHAT WAS THAT?”  

“SAM! WE’RE GOING TO GET DRINKS OK? SAVE US A TABLE YA?”  

“HUH?”  

Gabriel rolls his eyes, looking to the gaggle of girls and then gestures vaguely to Sam.
 “TABLE. SAVE ONE.” 

 “I-“  Before he can argue or voice any of the thoughts at the tip of his tongue, Gabriel yelps as Noor tugs him further into the dance floor. Seems she wants something to do with him. Sam stands there for a moment, collecting himself. The smoky perfumed air isn’t properly circulating through his lungs, he thinks. It's drowning him. He swims back through the gaggle of people to the sides.

With a gasp, he reaches the side of the room. The place seems to have widened, became liminal almost. It's hard to tell how far it is to the other side with the distance warped by fog. He grits his teeth as the house music hits a blaring note, his head still pounding. Note to self, ask for modificatory earphones or noise cancelling devices for future endeavours. He steadies himself with a hand to the wall, groans, and then looks around for an empty table.

Most of them are taken up, groups of all variety sitting lying or using the table in some way. But god seems to have thrown him a bone, as conveniently. there’s a free one only a ways away. And it only has a few empty and half full glasses as its occupants. As sam makes his way over, he concludes whoever they are, they sure shouldn't mind.

He moves the glasses to one side, and then sits down gingerly, placing his elbows on the table and his chin on his palms as his eyes roam the room, trying to pick Gabirel out in the crowd. The lighting makes it hard to pick out finer details, people flashing in and out from silhouette to colour in flashes. He feels queasy. He takes out his phone and starts searching medieval executions again.

His scrolling is interrupted by a man sitting down at the same table. He’s rather portly, his forehead beaded from sweat. Sam has the suspicion it’s from the outfit hes wearing, then from any physical exertion on the dance floor. The slightly unbuttoned shirt and tight dress pants do little to mitigate lend a pretty solid suspicion.

The man is breathing hard, his mouth open, as he fumbles for one of the glasses and finishes whatever was in it with a thirsty chug. He looks at Sam, and then at the dance floor. Tilts his head to Sam slightly, and speaking in a raised accented voice, addresses him.

 “Quite the party tonight ain’t it?”

  Sam blinks, raising his head from his phone. Not sure what to say, he nods.  

"Yeah it is.”  

“I tell you- can’t beat parties like this! Similar in case to uh- Dionysus and his extravagant parties of old in the woods- sex and drinks and pure human energy!

Silence. Sam only nods again.

"Know much about greek mythology my good man?” 

 “Yeah, somewhat.”  

“You look the type. What was the word for it.. Well read. Well read, yes that’s how you look.” 

Sam looks down to his phone again. Starts typing out queries on how to avoid awkward conversation. Where is Gabriel. He said he would be back with drinks a while ago. He hates this conversation. He hates this port, awkward man. He hates the air. He hates everyones smiling plastic faces. A waiter comes over, sliding a drink over wordlessly and leaves. The man doesn’t seem to take the hint, taking a swig from the new drink, making a loud satisfied noise and fixing him with a smile.

“You come here with anyone?”

  “Uh.. yeah.”

 “Who?”  Sams head is pounding. This guys voice is annoying. He scans the dance floor, and spots Gabriel, dancing amongst the group. Or at least he thinks so. He points to him mutely.  The man follows his pointed finger, looking back and forth between his wavering pointed hand and the direction hes pointing. Narrows his eyes as he seems to waver upon realizing who Sam seems to be pointing at. Clears his throat.

 “Well.. I suppose the place brings all types eh?”  

Sam fixes him with a stare. What the hell is this man talking about. Does he think Gabriels outfit is weird?  The man swallows, and then makes a quick exit, mumbling something about seeing a colleague somewhere elsewhere. Sam doesn’t wave back.

———

Out on the dance floor, it’s all color, noise, and sound. Gabriel laughs along as people dance their hearts out and move to the sound of the room, the rhythm an organ that beats within them. Noor is grinning and purposefully teasing at him by pressing against him as she dances, and giving him a knowing look.

Oh, he sees how this is. Never one to turn down a good challenge, he teases her in kind, matching the tempo and showing off a fair bit just to be dramatic.

Noor squeals, clapping her hands as she gets more frisky with it, shamoosing her body over to his as he does likewise and letting out a laugh as soon enough they match rhythms. An exchange without words, all body, all movement, until he's got his fingers intertwined with hers and their bodies are pressed against each other. She’s pressed up against his chest as she gives him bedroom eyes. Gabriel smiles.  

 “Hellooo darling.”

  With a gasp she squeezes his hand in hers, giggling as she presses against him, her free hand walking up his chest as she purrs. 

 “Heeyyy. Come here often?”  

“No but a little devil from hell itself charmed me down here, would you believe that?”  

She snickers, her hand squeezing his arm as she turns her head to press against his chest.   “Ohh you’re too cute. Say.. wanna head somewhere more.. private? Mm?” 

 “Thought you’d never ask.”

  She tugs his shirt, biting her lip devilishly as she turns around and starts making her way through the crowd. Up a set of stairs, through corridors, and then to one that’s more empty, private.   “Turn around.”  Gabriel complies, turning around and facing the wall as he listens to her punch in a code to the door. It beeps and there’s the sound of a lock opening.   

“Ok come on.”  She grabs him by the wrist, closing the door behind him a bit breathlessly. A hallway greets him with its stark white walls, wooden paneled floor, and black doors. It’s a stark contrast to the party below, and a glimpse of what the house probably looks like in the daylight, when it's not full of rowdy rich partygoers. The music is quieter here, muffled by the soundproof walls. Gabriel only gets a glimpse before they’re walking into a bedroom, the lights turning on automatically as they enter. A large bed sits in the middle of the room, paneled wardrobe on the left, master bathroom on the right. She walks ahead of him, giving a little sigh as she moves to hop onto the cushy bed, spreading herself on it and beckoning to him.

Gabriel takes a deep breath, eyes flicking over her body before he shakes his head with a smile, raising his hands. He unbuttons a few of the buttons of his shirt before moving to get on the bed with her, pressing her down as with a happy little sigh, she wraps her arms around his neck and starts pressing kisses into his skin.

He lets her, hands undoing each and every strap on the back of her dress as she presses against him. Their lips press against each other, her mouth locking against his as he closes his eyes, engaged in a passionate kiss as her hands card through his hair.

She’s so focused, she doesn’t feel the prick of a small sharp needle into the back of her neck as his fingers press against her skin.

Her eyes flutter. Gabriel presses her down. It’ll be okay, he wants to say. But it’s best to let the mind fill in the blanks naturally for when she wakes up. Things like this can just cause trouble.

Amnestics can be a hell of a punch.

She’s out in a minute, breaths rising and falling softly as Gabriel pulls away from her, buttoning his shirt back up and grabbing his belt. As much as he’d like to continue, it’s best to leave it for the after mission celebration. Now, to see about what this place was.

Opening the door, he takes out his phone.

“Sam.”  No response.   “Saaam. You there? Don’t tell me you’re too busy talking it up to a group of hot babes and have left me out in the cold.” A moment of silence, broken by a typing chat bubble popping up and then-  “I’m not.”  

There he is.

"How's it going down there?"

"Bad."

"Yeah, anyways, any hope of getting into the smart home system?"

Sams little indicator displays as seen for all of two minutes while Gabriel paces. He's halfway to asking Sam if he's passed out at the table when he starts typing again.

"I'm in."

"That was fast. Go ahead and navigate to the top floor. You see me?"

Another few moments. Then a response.

"Yes."

"Great. Keep your sights around the area."

"You sure you don't want me to try and look for auspicious areas?"

Gabriel ignores him. He's got it, pretty sure. Besides, there's fun in exploring.

He tries the door opposite the bedroom. Another bedroom. From somewhere in the room, he knows Sam is watching him. This one has a darker palette than the more neutral hues of the other bedroom, and smells of cologne. There's a computer set up in the corner, prompting his attention. He takes out a USBdrive from his pocket, twirling it before pushing it into the input slot.

The thing flickers, lines of code breaking down the defenses of the machine as Gabriel runs a cursory eye over the documents on the table. A proposition to set back funds for a certain subdivision of the marketing departmnet. A request to move the finish date of a building over by a year. Nothing of note, to him.

The computer shows a blue screen, indicating it's done scraping data. He tugs it out, inspecting the USB drive before turning to the rest of the room and giving it a look over.

He decides he'll come back later. Best to cover all the points to some extent before delving into one specific scrub down.

He makes for another door. Walking into the room, he cam immediately tell this is where the money is at.

It's an office. The lights are off, but moonlight shines in from the large bay windows to the left of the office, fluttering slightly in the draft. The moon illuminates the handsome wood paneling of the walls, The black leather couches seated around a coffee table, and the desk at the far end of the room, a red chair and a large painting behind it.

Jackpot.

These places are veritable treasure troves. He heads over to the table, starts opening each and every drawer as he taps the computer awake. He repeats the process of taking out another thumbdrive and pressing it in as he searches in a more traditional way.

Stationary. A gun. Paperwork. A watch.

It's not really necessary to search in this way, he knows, but he enjoys the process. A way of getting hands on into the heads of others. The small eccentricities.

Suddenly all the lights cut off. His phone buzzes.

"Someone's coming. Hide."

Gabriels head whips up to the screen. 87%. Still needs a bit more time.

He scans the room. A wardrobe. Curtains. Nowhere to really hide.

There's the sound of heels clacking on wooden flooring. It gets closer to the door. 90%. Holy shit will it load faster?

Gabriel curses under his breath, smacking the table to try and make it go faster. It doesn't. There's not enough time, he yanks it out and turns the computer off, ducking under the desk.

And just in time too, as the door clicks and light hits the office chair as Gabriel huddles underneath, trying to keep his frame small as the figure, whoever they are, stands for a long moment in the hall door.

It walks in, heels tapping as with slow deliberate steps, it stalks over to the far side of the room. There's the sound of rifling through papers, and a small exhale. The papers are put down, and Gabriel strains his ears to keep a rough estimate of where the figure is.

It turns. Takes a few steps in an indeterminable direction before striding over to stand in front of the desk. He looks down to note her dark two inch platformed boots.

It stays there for what feels like a dragged out couple of moments, Gabriel watching the shoes before it turns, heading out of view, and stops somewhere at the wall to the right.

He hears a clatter as something is removed, and then a sigh as with the clack of a bracelet, they start punching in a code. A whirr, as what he can presume is a safe opens, and something is removed.

He wishes he could see what it was. It's hard to tell. Either way, the figure only lingers a few moments there, before closing the safe, replacing the cover of the hidden panel, and leaving the room.
